Comment: Let me add just a little truth in advertising to this statement.  Anecdotal, but it's real world.  This will be a little long, but let me tell my story.  In 2017 I had kidney failure from a bad reaction to a medication.  I drew the short straw.  That proverbial bus came out of nowhere and hit me.  My life, career, dreams all stopped.  I had to go on disability and dialysis.  This made me eligible for Medicare and Medicaid.  I'll skip over the nearly four years of headache and heartache that was dealing with it all. But, in 2021 I was very lucky and received a transplant.  The rules currently say that after a transplant you are allowed to keep Medicare for up to 36 months.  The only exception is if the kidney is rejected and you must go back on dialysis.  Then, it can continue.  I have done well post transplant, but not perfect.  I struggle with stamina / energy, pain and numbess, polycythemia, have issues with medications that leads to days I can barely even get out of bed, experience immune suppression issues meaning I have to be very careful around people, and require regular very expensive treatments (infusions / phlebotomies, etc.) to stay stable and alive.  In February of 2024 I hit my three years post transplant.  Even though I am not physically able to return to work full time according to my care team the SSA deemed me able to return to work because I was not back on dialysis.  My care team appealed, but to no avail.  I could have hired an attorney, but chose not to.  I was tired of fighting and optimistic about the future.  As such I lost Medicare, Disability, SNAP, and all assistance except Medicaid.     I am eligible for Medicaid because I am in an expansion state and am way below the income limit.  When I lost disability I started a very small lapidary business that earns me a little money.  I had no choice, you have to have some income.  It's home based and allows me to do what I can, when I can.  Barely enough to get by.  Less than I received from Disability each month.  A lot less.  If it wasn't for Medicaid I would not be able to afford the medications I need to live and the treatments that keep me alive.  I could not pay a monthly premium, plus any out of pocket.  My medications alone are nearly $2000 a month.  One treatment, which I need every three months or so, is $4000.  This all adds up fast.  Thanks to Trump's tariffs my small business is about to go under.  The 145% tariff on China coupled with the de minimus elimination has crippled my business.  Even my primary wholesaler is no longer shipping to the United States.  Once my current stock is gone I'm done unless something changes.  Then, what?  Will I now lose my healthcare, too?  That's a sob story I know, but it's also real life.  A version of it is playing out all over the country right now.  People unable to work for one reason or another, but not able to qualify for disability, or still fighting through the multi-year process to be approved for disability, are scared they will lose the healthcare that keeps them alive.  Personally, if I lose Medicaid, I lose my life.  There's no inbetween.  No meds, no kidney... no life.  It's just that simple.    So, let me make this a little personal.  Hello, my name is Cliff.  I beg of you, please tell your Reps to not vote to take away healthcare from and maybe even end up killing people like me.  We didn't do anything to you.  We just want to live and be as healthy as we can.  We want to be with our families and friends.  We want to try to contribute to society in some way.  We matter to someone and they matter to us.  Please don't forget that there are people, real people, behind these policy discussions.  We're more than just statistics.  We are people, too.

Comment: As a semi-able bodied person, the biggest barrier is having a consistent primary care doctor. You have to submit paperwork annually indicating why you can’t work full time or whatever their work requirement hours are. It’s not difficult in terms of getting or staying on benefits, but it is complicated if you don’t have an ongoing relationship with a good enough doctor.  Also, most people on Medicaid and nearly all people on Medicaid Expansion are already working.   Alabama or Georgia already tried work requirements and it was so bad they stopped it. It’s nearly impossible for the Medicaid office to stay up with current paperwork requirements. Adding monthly work verification paperwork resulted in tons of qualified people not getting benefits. Which I know is the point. But it is fucking stupid. Not being insured costs far more than just giving qualified people Medicaid.
